Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a 400-MHz NMR Spectrometer for Research and Teaching
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program, Professor Terry Gullion from West Virginia University and colleagues Kung Wang, Bjorn Soderberg, Xiaodong Shi and Brian Popp will acquire a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer that would replace two 270 MHz instruments that are over 20 years old. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in many areas that support organic chemistry and catalysis such as (a) expanding the organometallic catalysis toolbox; (b) development of synthetic reactions affording nitrogen-containing heterocycles and carbocyclic compounds; (c) transition metal catalyzed reductive cyclization of nitroaromatic compounds; (d) base or photochemically promoted cyclizations of nitroaromatic compounds; (e) annulation reactions of alpha,beta-unsaturated Fischer carbene complexes; (f) synthetic methods for functional 1,2,3-triazoles; and (g) molecular architectures of nonplanar polycyclic aromatic.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research at West Virginia University and neighboring institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer was purchased from Agilent and installed in the Department of Chemistry at West Virginia University in April 2013. NMR spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The acquisition of the 400 NMR spectrometer has had significant impact on several research projects involving chemical transformations of organic and organometallic compounds and has greatly enhanced the opportunities to introduce the full range of NMR technologies to students.

New synthetic pathways to nitrogen-containing compounds possessing interesting biological activities have been developed. The use of new organometallic compounds for catalysis and for specific chemical transformations not easily achievable by other methods have been discovered. In addition, a new and more general approach for the construction of carbon nanohoops as potential templates for growing carbon nanotubes of a uniform diameter and structural arrangement has been developed. A new synthetic pathway for thiophene-containing carbon nanohoops for potential applications in nanotechnology fields has been established. These new discoveries expand the toolbox for catalysis and organic and organometallic chemistry, providing new ways for the synthesis of biologically active compounds and the construction of new materials for nanotechnology applications.

The research and educational components of this project were integrated by providing postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate students with hands-on experience in the operation of a state-of-the-art NMR spectrometer. They were also afforded the opportunities to design new NMR experiments and to use the NMR data for structural elucidation. The development of well-trained chemists with NMR skills adds to the human resources for chemical and pharmaceutical industries. In addition, many of the undergraduate students at West Virginia University are from populations that are underrepresented in higher education and are low-income first-generation students. Providing the opportunity to involve these students in undergraduate research and in course work with the use of a sophisticated NMR spectrometer during their college years is helpful in persuading them to choose STEM fields in general and chemistry in particular for their careers.
